author: dareftw
body:
It’s pretty true. I have a BS in Economics and an MA in applied economics and an MQM (Masters in Quantitative Management) as well. And the first question people ask when they find out what I did in college is about the economy and stocks. And it’s a dumb question and they don’t even realize it. Like I spent years learning about scarcity and a bunch of basically applied calculus and statistics. 

Unless I work directly for a brokerage I wouldn’t have enough time to make an informed decision any one way or the other, and even then it would only be a best estimate and one with enough of a likely chance to not be correct that it would be pretty irresponsible to give an opinion on it. 

I can fully do the math behind it sure, but the stock market has proven time and time again that it’s irrational and not really predictable with any algorithm. There is a reason that economic theory even says throwing a dart at a chart of stocks and picking where it lands is just as likely to be accurate than if you picked it based on extensive amounts of DD and research. 

But I just point people towards index’s, tell them if they aren’t retiring in the next 5 years don’t be afraid or worried that the stock market drops every now and then etc etc. 

tl;dr Economists don’t study the economy they study scarcity. I’d be extremely skeptical of any economist claiming to know what the market will do or that they have figured out the stock market. We exist to do small scale data analysis, or to advise large scale economic moves aka monetary/fiscal policy, we aren’t adept at guessing small movements within certain markets. And if we’re in a spot where we can then we are also in a spot where the sec would have something to say if we profited off it.

author: Okmanl
body:
Most fund managers don’t beat the market. Because they’re not trying to. Many fund managers and professional investors also have regulations they have to follow. They can’t make concentrated investments. They have to show quarterly results and so forth. For example Cathy Wood said she would’ve put a lot more into Tesla but because of rules and regulations the max she can invest is ~10% per fund she manages. 


Individual investors can definitely beat the market by having a concentrated portfolio. Knowing the stock that they own intimately and not letting emotions get involved. 

There are quite a few people who have a concentrated portfolio on 3-4 companies like Square, peloton, Tesla, Amazon, Microsoft, AMD and so forth. And they have all outperformed the market over 5-10 years. 

If you have a high risk tolerance then buying single stocks can be worth it.

author: WrongWeekToQuit
body:
I still see the comparisons...

You had outright fraud from Enron, Worldcom, etc... not unlike Lickin, Wirecard, Nikola.

You had companies with high valuations that confounded the people who tried to value them like Amazon.  The same things being said of Tesla were said about Amazon back then.

You had tech darlings like Microsoft, Cisco, Oracle, Intel, etc... that ran up huge amounts, making employees into millionaires.

You had highly anticipated IPOs of companies, some very immature like pets.com, but some big like doubleclick, etc... If you look at Big Commerce's or Lemonade's financials, they aren't great.  And some of the SPAC mergers are pretty suspect especially when compared to how much they run up around merger time.  

I agree that there was more vaporware back in the late 90s, BUT, the fervor, the blind investing into companies without knowing anything about their financials, the double or triple digit gains within a single year.... remind you of any recent times?

author: Stonksflyingup
body:
What kind of price-to-sales multiple will GME have in the next 2 years? Currently at 0.13

If GME successfully grows their e-commerce business to \~50% with same day delivery (currently being rolled out now), the products they sell could reasonably provide a 1x sales multiple. (Compare other e-commerce P/S - OSTK 1.2   CHWY 4.2)

4 new revenue streams for GME will include: Monetization of customer data, digital downstream revenue from MSFT Xbox platform, online advertising revenue, and PC hardware sales. All 4 offer good margins.

All of these new revenue streams and e-commerce growth represents a very big change (almost 'tech' like) than that of the former business model of purely B&M with mostly just gaming product inventory. The real big money to influence a major share price rise is in the customer data. If leveraged properly, GME has a true 'tech' side to their business model.

GME looks to grow revenue YoY, estimating 6-7bn for 2021, and 8bn+ in 2022 with a P/S of 1, we are looking at a 8bn market cap in 2022. Share price of $120+

You could compare with BestBuy, which has a P/S of 0.8. Give GME the 0.8 P/S and they reach a market cap of 6.4bn (assuming 8bn yearly revenue in 2022). That's $99/share and an 800% increase from current market value.

Most investors are not aware of what the company has to offer, hence why the reference Blockbuster so much. There is a reason we have seen larger stakes being taken by bigger players. Just last week we saw some more big boys jumping in. Wells Fargo, Jefferies, Hussman all taking positions. When GME shorts flip to longs (will happen eventually) they will drive up the share price.

In the next 2 years, if the street decides to view GME as a e-commerce/digital data business within the gaming/PC industry, valuations can run high and P/S multiples could run even higher.

author: Stonksflyingup
body:
Here is why I am bullish and willing to hold long term.

**Monetization of customer data** \- possible 600M EBITDA if leveraged correctly. Why nobody mentions this is beyond me, arguably one of the most important high margin revenue streams GME can benefit from.

**E-Commerce omnichannel business model** that offers same day delivery and is continually improving. This is the "beat AMZN' part of the business model.

**PC hardware sales** ($40bn/yr and growing TAM)

**Online ad revenue.** From website + App

**E-sports experiences**. Currently partnering with gaming pros and streaming on twitch. Will **build brand recognition**.

Massive **reduction in SG&A.**

**SKU optimization**. Better inventory and inventory turnover.

'Digital everything' is not as strong of a bear thesis as it was 2 years ago. Especially considering GME has the MSFT partnership to share digital revenue.

Gaming industry TAM is growing YoY.

Competent management team. Finally.

Bigger firms/institutions are taking a position in GME. So far as of end of Q3 we have had new or increased stakes from: Senvent, State Street, Russell, Wells Fargo, Hussman and finally Jefferies taking an sizeable position in Call options.

&#x200B;

This is not a $700MM company. This is not the old GME where you simply buy and trade in videogames. It is very undervalued at current market price of $11

I think GME has potential to be valued at $2-3bn valuation within 12 months ($32-47)

When it finally appreciates in value after a few good quarterly earnings then there should be a slow squeeze. You have to be patient with this play. It will most likely take 6+ months until we see good Q4 and Q1 earnings to convince shorts to capitulate.

author: Mirikado
body:
Yeah, I don’t see as much growth potential in FB like MSFT and AMZN. Facebook (the site) itself has been viewed quite negatively by the younger generation, and it might go the way of MySpace, if there’s a newer and cooler social media platform in town. Facebook’s Oculus Quest is a success and can be big for them, but the VR market is still very niche. 

Amazon has a ton of upsides, especially during and even after COVID, where everything will move towards online, everyone already knew. Despite how big Amazon is, eCommerce is still only 16% of retail sale, so there’s still room. Cloud is booming, and AWS is still king.

I am the most bullish on MSFT. They have a good mix of the old stuff that have been steadily making them money for decades and are still here to stay (Windows, Office/365, .NET, SQL, Xbox) and the cool new stuff that has a lot of growth potential (Azure/Cloud, Surface, GamePass, Teams). On top of that, their recent acquisitions have been doing a lot better than the failed ones in the past. I think MSFT is very solid, and they are one killer product away from taking over Apple as the #1 company in term of market cap, again.

author: Ackilles
body:
Wall street expectations for gamestop are bottom of the barrel.  They still think its going bankrupt soon.  Normally this would be their worst earnings of the console cycle, but the last one had forced store closures.  I'm thinking we see better numbers this quarter. And better than worst will be a surprise.

That said, I've been saying for months that I expect the stock to drop on EPS posting for Decembers ER, but I expect a huge rally during the call.  They will absolutely talk about console presales and interest.  That itself is pretty bullish.  They're sold out of preorders and will continue to be even after the next batch drops.

This will also be a great time to talk about other activities.  Is Cohen taking an active roll in the turnaround?  He is still invested, so this is still very feasible, and an official announcement that he is actively involved would be good for at least +2-3 bucks tacked onto the stock price.

Talking about continued increase in website sales and how people are responding to the massive improvements is also a likely topic.  If they don't bring up the MSFT deal, there will absolutely be questions from investors about it.  If they start forward guidance again, we could see crazy movement on that as well.


Finally, and rather amusingly, a lack of console supply is actually bullish for GME.  People start selling used consoles to gamestop starting the day they release.  Why?  I can't fathom a legitimate reason for this, but it happens.  Super demand and no supply means people will pay new console prices for used consoles.  There will be a massive profit margin on these for gamestop, and even better, when the console is an XBox, that console starts generating passive revenue for them as well.

author: braamdepace
body:
Agreed, but one thing I will add is this... when the market drops big often times it’s hard to look at your account it’s frustrating and you almost want to ignore it, or forget about it like a bad grade, relationship, bill or anything else that causes anxiety...  but it’s at this time you need to calm your emotions and spend more time researching and critically thinking about your account.

Also you will have big losses, and it’s hard to sell those even though there is much better places for your money.  One of the examples I will give you is from me personally this year.  I had 25% my account in BAC-K.  This is a preferred callable stock that trades around $25 and pays 7% dividend payment.  When the market crashed this “crashed” too.  It dropped to $20 (a 20% drop) and I was pissed cause it shouldn’t have moved that much cause I knew BAC was capable of making the dividend payment and they had to pay me before their common shareholders.  As much as I didn’t want to sell this stock knowing it would recover back to $25 pretty easily I had to force myself to realize that there were other stocks out there that lost much more and long term were better spots for my money.  Companies like MSFT, AAPL, and other amazing companies dropped 35-50%... this was an opportunity I wouldn’t get again and as hard as it was I had to realize I had time and some risk tolerance to take advantage of this opportunity.  So I knew selling a stock that had no business being down 20% at a loss and repositioning would be more beneficial long term.

TLDR when shit hits the fan it’s natural to pull out or ignore your account, but you have to fight that urge.  It’s at that time you double down on research and evaluating your financial situation.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
"Tech firms (generally) make their money through advertising."

Some. Many do not - semiconductors, enterprise software, etc.

Even advertising - look at ad-focused businesses. Cardlytics, Roku, Trade Desk, etc. Yes, was difficult for a brief period in March and April but has recovered considerably. If you bought any of these at the lows you've done exceptionally. 

"Surely that means they stand to take a hit by proxy if consumers have less money in their pockets due to job losses within other industries?"

There's been countless discussions by companies that many aspects of the current crisis have forced further adoption of technology and pulled forward years of growth. Businesses are spending on tech. That's why you have SaaS companies up 100-200-300%+ YTD.

Satya Nadella on Microsoft's quarterly call about a week ago: 

"The way I think about the computing landscape going forward is if you sort of said at the highest of levels today as a percentage of GDP, tech spend is 5%. We think it will double in the next 10 years. And if anything, this pandemic perhaps has accelerated that doubling. And in that context, what’s the large -- the most secular need, it’s the need for distributed cloud infrastructure. It’s both needed for modernizing existing applications you have, and so that’s why -- by the way, 20% penetrated, so there’s more 80% that needs to move. But more importantly, there’s going to be new application starts which need infrastructure. And so, if you sort of add those up, I think that we’re still in early innings. There will be between quarters, volatility, all of the points that Amy made even earlier. But, we think distributed cloud infrastructure is the most important layer. But, the way we’ve approached it is not to just think of that layer in isolation but the data layer work we do composes, the AI layer composes and more importantly, our SaaS applications, whether business applications, Power Platform, Microsoft 365, all reinforce that same modern tech stack. So, I would still say that digitization in its -- this new tech stack is in its very infancy."

In the Spring, Nadella:  “We’ve seen two years’ worth of digital transformation in two months."

"consumers have less money in their pockets due to job losses within other industries?"

Consumer tech? Yes, unfortunately there are a lot of people who are not doing well. But there's still plenty of people who are doing well and who are buying the latest phone - people are streaming, they're constantly looking at the news with everything going on, etc. The phone is a staple at this point. Video games are doing exceptionally well. 

You also had a complete trade off this year and there were some companies that lost out and some that benefited. Apparel lost. Travel lost. That money went into home furnishings and technology as people stayed home. I think technology spending is becoming more and more a priority with each passing year and this year accelerated that considerably, but there was certainly an aspect of people didn't spend on A and B so that money went to C and D.

author: Okmanl
body:
Most fund managers don’t beat the market. Because they’re not trying to. Many fund managers and professional investors also have regulations they have to follow. They can’t make concentrated investments. They have to show quarterly results and so forth. For example Cathy Wood said she would’ve put a lot more into Tesla but because of rules and regulations the max she can invest is ~10% per fund she manages. 


Individual investors can definitely beat the market by having a concentrated portfolio. Knowing the stock that they own intimately and not letting emotions get involved. 

There are quite a few people who have a concentrated portfolio on 3-4 companies like Square, peloton, Tesla, Amazon, Microsoft, AMD and so forth. And they have all outperformed the market over 5-10 years. 

If you have a high risk tolerance then buying single stocks can be worth it.

author: AngelaQQ
body:
Japan’s lost decades was a combination of fiscal mismanagement, overbearing debt load, and complete lack of technology growth, leading to stagnation.  

As a result, Japanese investors and savers pulled their money from the Nikkei and put it into US equities. Equities like Microsoft, Apple, Sun, Oracle saw a huge influx of Japanese capital as their markets stagnated.  

Even today, none of Japan’s top 20 companies by market cap are internet or software/tech companies. 

They’ve basically missed the boat on every single technological revolution of the past 30 years.

I’m not as worried about the US, because the US (and China) are the world leaders in technological innovation in almost all major sectors.

If there IS for some reason a lost decade in the US, China will benefit, as they are the only country that can compete technologically, and their debt position vis a vis the rest of world is favorable.

* How old are you? **23**

* What are your objectives with this money? (buy a house? Not sure how much of the returns from the market I will use on this vs. taking out a loan. So otherwise, I am looking for retirement savings**
* What is your risk tolerance? (Do you mind risking it at blackjack or do you need to know its 100% safe?) **I've got a long time horizon so my tolerance is fairly high**
* What are you current holdings? (Do you already have exposure to specific funds and sectors?) **None**
* Any other assets? House paid off? Cars? Expensive significant other? **$20k in cash, plus I am looking to invest at least half of my salary this year since I am living with my parents and have no expenses.**
* What is your time horizon? Do you need this money next month? Next 20yrs? **I am prepared to hold onto my investments up until retirement, though I MIGHT want to take some money out to pay for business school/house**
* Any big debts? **None**
* Any other relevant financial information will be useful to give you a proper answer. **None**

The allocation I am considering is:

author: CallidusVulpes
body: Nvidia is a safe investment in the long run (they might go down a bit this month though due to AMD, but overall Nvidia has went up consistently over the past 5 years and has shown no signs of deviating significantly from that), Microsoft is safe, Tesla is too scary for me personally. I don't buy ETFs or evaluate them, I evaluate individual stocks then choose whether or not I would like to purchase them. I play for large short term gains (large relative to my investment portfolio and short meaning a few months typically). I've made a 17.49% profit in the past 2 weeks (starting with 2k) due to making "all in" bets on Corsair (to be clear to do this I was incredibly confident it was going to go up, but I definitely wouldn't advise it if you do not need the money, I have a stupidly low retirement target). Corsair was likely my most risky investment that's why I left quickly. AMD and TSMC are great investments for a couple of years, probably 3 years or more (TSMC almost definitely 3 years or more since they make the most powerful CPUs that go in the new Xbox, PS5, AMD CPUs, Apple CPUs, and they even have Intel waiting in line since their factories are all in use). You'll almost definitely hate my diversity, but I'm likely going to buy all AMD and TSMC (In my opinion diversity is for people who don't know much about the market they are invested in or don't feel like keeping up with the news). If I were to make a more long-term safer account I'd buy NVidia, Apple, AMD, and TSMC (Diversification in different sectors doesn't help if the entire market goes down, and I don't believe these specific tech stocks have exited a year down for the past decade (I know at least for the past 5 years they haven't), except for AMD which completely changed as a company). I'm putting all of my money on AMD and TSMC once the market opens tomorrow (I'd recommend stocking up ASAP on those stocks since they had a bad day on Friday). Apple will likely not see that much growth if any this quarter, but they'll be great for the long term. If you don't have the stomach or patience for seeing temporary losses then I would not recommend tech (Microsoft isn't too bad actually). I've sat on 200 USD losses (which is 10% of my portfolio) and went positive 145 USD the next day (that was my worst timed trade with Corsair). This probably looks very frantic, sorry, I'm a bit too excited.

author: RepresentativeIcy922
body:
It's easy to see that Zoom is (was?) undervalued. People are having more meetings online because of covid-19, and a lot of them are using Zoom. It seems everywhere you look someone has an online meeting on Zoom. Schools that are closed have classes on Zoom.   
Zoom seems to be like the Microsoft of online meetings these days, it's the de-facto industry standard for online meetings. So on that basis alone, Zoom seems undervalued (at this point in time.) 

They're more popular now than they ever were, and that potentially means more money, and that in turn means the price might go up.   


The thing about active trading is, well, that it's active. The fund managers try to figure out what will go up and buy it, and sell it before it drops. They're more momentum players than long-term holders, so I guess based on that alone they might buy Zoom (because everyone seems to be using it these days, and that can't be a bad thing as far as the price is concerned (for now anyway.)  


There was a lot of hype around Zoom, and when it appeared on a lot of people's radars it was a lot cheaper than it is now.  They would have likely bought in when they first started seeing all those ads for seminars on Zoom, and notices of schools being closed and having classes on Zoom.

author: StarWolf478
body:
The big two for me are:

Netflix - The Q2 lockdown was the absolute most perfect condition imaginable for Netflix's business and anybody that had any interest in Netflix should have already subscribed by that point in time. I think that there now has to be some significant growth slowdown after such perfect business conditions start to come to an end. Plus, more and more competitors are entering the market to compete for Netflix's subscribers while also pulling their content from Netflix which forces Netflix to spend more money to develop their own content. All of that makes me think that Netflix cannot maintain the high growth that they have had thus far and if they can't maintain that growth then investors will eventually start to abandon them. I'm still bullish on streaming though, so I've invested in Roku instead as my streaming stock since they are the "picks and shovels seller" for the "streaming gold rush" and unlike Netflix, they benefit from the increased competition entering the streaming market.

Google - They have started to remind me of Microsoft during the Steve Ballmer era. When was the last time that Google successfully executed upon a great new product and didn't ultimately send it to ever growing [Google Graveyard](https://killedbygoogle.com/)? I think that it has been about a decade and they have just been living off of their successes from over a decade ago since then. Maybe Google will eventually get new management that revitalizes the company like Microsoft eventually got after Nadella became CEO, but for the foreseeable future, I've lost confidence in them, so I'm out. I've replaced them with Pinterest in my portfolio as my new search/advertising stock. Social search is the future and I now see the genius advertising potential of the Pinterest platform; I see them stealing advertising dollars away from Google and growing much better than Google over the next 5 years.

author: thewimsey
body:
MSFT wasn't  a computer company. It was a software company. IBM was a computer company.

The brilliance of MSFT was in - and this seems weird today - realizing that a company could make money just selling software. A ton of money. More money than computer makers could make by themselves. This was a kind of radical idea at the time.

Jobs was very successful at the computer business; the Apple was the bestselling PC from 1977-1982.

Apple wasn't killed by MSFT, it was killed by IBM, which built a PC from more or less off the shelf parts allowing *anyone* to build a clone. (Which, incidentally, would run windows). 

Apple's computers couldn't compete with PCs built with off the shelf parts. It's not about Jobs being bad; it's about other people being better.

IBM's approach almost immediately priced *them* out of the PC market, leaving the profits to MSFT and intel (and a tiny bit for clone makers, who mostly ended up in a low margin commodity business).

author: Henkss
body:
Thing is big tech will always thrive. Look at their earnings, revenue, pile of cash on Balance sheet. Little to no debt..

Until a new disruptive technology emerges (in what form we do not know) - whatever big comes out of internet/robotics/AI space/Data, big tech will absorb it right away. It's all about data. Something interesting will emerge, and it will be bought right away. Why do you think these companies have more cash than most countries combined.

Sure they can go lower in the short run but what do you think is going to happen a year from now.

Do we think MSFT adding 8-10% rev growth on a 40bn revenue company will be $100 per share? Kingpin Bezos? Daddy Cook? Zuck?

If big tech was supposed to go down, they should have been broken apart already. It is too late now. Only thing that can disrupt is a complete new technology - the way green tech reshaping energy industry.
